isaInvestigation.title: Investigation
isaInvestigation.description: Created using the MetaboLights Online Editor (MOE)

studies.title: Differential role of sphingomyelin in influenza virus, rhinovirus and SARS-CoV-2 infection of Calu-3 cells
studies.description: Host cell lipids play a pivotal role in the pathogenesis of respiratory virus infection. However, a direct comparison of the lipidomic profile of influenza virus and rhinovirus infections is lacking. In this study, we first compared the lipid profile of influenza virus and rhinovirus infection in a bronchial epithelial cell line. Most lipid features were downregulated for both influenza virus and rhinovirus, especially for the sphingomyelin features. Pathway analysis showed that sphingolipid metabolism was the most perturbed pathway. Functional study showed that bacterial sphingomyelinase suppressed influenza virus and severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) replication, but promoted rhinovirus replication. These findings suggest that sphingomyelin pathway can be a potential target for antiviral therapy, but should be carefully evaluated as it has opposite effects on different respiratory viruses. Furthermore, the differential effect of sphingomyelinase on rhinovirus and influenza virus may explain the interference between rhinovirus and influenza virus infection.

publications.title: Differential role of sphingomyelin in influenza virus, rhinovirus and SARS-CoV-2 infection of Calu-3 cells.
publications.authorList: Dissanayake TK, Yan B, Ng AC, Zhao H, Chan G, Yip CC, Sze KH, To KK.

protocols.name: Sample collection
protocols.description:
Viruses and cells:

The viruses used in this study were all isolated from patients as we described previously, including influenza A(H1N1) virus A/HK/415742/2009[1][2], influenza B virus B/HK/411989/2011[2], rhinovirus 451892/2011 (belongs to rhinovirus species A type 1A)[3], and SARS-CoV-2 HKU001a[4][5].


Influenza A and influenza B viruses were propagated in Madin Darby canine kidney (MDCK) cells at 37 °C, while rhinovirus was propagated in human rhabdomyosarcoma cells (RD cells) at 33 °C. Plaque number was determined on MDCK cells for influenza A virus and influenza B virus, and on HELA-H1 cells (ATCC CRL-1958) for rhinovirus. Human lung carcinoma cells Calu-3 (ATCC, HTB-55) were used for infection assays. Calu-3 cells were grown in Dulbecco’s Modified Eagle Medium/Nutrient Mixture F-12 (DMEM-F12) media, 2.5% HEPES and 10% foetal bovine serum (FBS). Cell lines are authenticated by Pangenia Lifesciences Ltd every half year.


Infection and cell lysate collection:

Infection and lipid extraction were performed as we described previously with modifications[6]-[9]. Briefly, Calu-3 cells were seeded on 6-well plate at 2.5 x 10^6 cells per well, and were mock-infected or infected with influenza A virus or rhinovirus at a multiplicity of infection (MOI) of 1 or 5 and incubated in DMEM/F12 medium in 6-well plates at 37 °C. At 1 h post-infection (hpi), the viruses were removed and the cells were washed by phosphate buffered saline (PBS). At 12 hpi, the supernatant was removed, and the cells were washed using 1 ml ice-cold quenching buffer twice (60% methanol and 0.85% ammonium bicarbonate in H2O). Then, 550 µl of ice-cold 150 mM ammonium bicarbonate solution was added to dissociate cells. The cells were then scraped and transferred into 15 ml tubes (Nunc, Thermo Fisher, USA) on ice.


Refs:

[1] Zheng B, Chan KH, Zhang AJ, Zhou J, Chan CC, Poon VK, Zhang K, Leung VH, Jin DY, Woo PC, Chan JF, To KK, Chen H, Yuen KY. D225G mutation in hemagglutinin of pandemic influenza H1N1 (2009) virus enhances virulence in mice. Exp Biol Med (Maywood). 2010 Aug;235(8):981-8. doi:10.1258/ebm.2010.010071. PMID:20660098.

[2] To KKW, Mok KY, Chan ASF, Cheung NN, Wang P, Lui YM, Chan JFW, Chen H, Chan KH, Kao RYT, Yuen KY. Mycophenolic acid, an immunomodulator, has potent and broad-spectrum in vitro antiviral activity against pandemic, seasonal and avian influenza viruses affecting humans. J Gen Virol. 2016 Aug;97(8):1807-1817. doi:10.1099/jgv.0.000512. PMID:27259985.

[3] Dissanayake TK, Schäuble S, Mirhakkak MH, Wu WL, Ng AC, Yip CCY, López AG, Wolf T, Yeung ML, Chan KH, Yuen KY, Panagiotou G, To KK. Comparative Transcriptomic Analysis of Rhinovirus and Influenza Virus Infection. Front Microbiol. 2020 Jul 21;11:1580. doi:10.3389/fmicb.2020.01580. Erratum in: Front Microbiol. 2020 Oct 29;11:602854. PMID:32849329.

[4] Zhao H, To KKW, Sze KH, Yung TT, Bian M, Lam H, Yeung ML, Li C, Chu H, Yuen KY. A broad-spectrum virus- and host-targeting peptide against respiratory viruses including influenza virus and SARS-CoV-2. Nat Commun. 2020 Aug 25;11(1):4252. doi:10.1038/s41467-020-17986-9. PMID:32843628.

[5] Chu H, Chan JF, Yuen TT, Shuai H, Yuan S, Wang Y, Hu B, Yip CC, Tsang JO, Huang X, Chai Y et al. Comparative tropism, replication kinetics, and cell damage profiling of SARS-CoV-2 and SARS-CoV with implications for clinical manifestations, transmissibility, and laboratory studies of COVID-19: an observational study. Lancet Microbe. 2020 May;1(1):e14-e23. doi:10.1016/S2666-5247(20)30004-5. PMID:32835326.

[6] Yuan S, Chu H, Chan JF, Ye ZW, Wen L, Yan B, Lai PM, Tee KM, Huang J et al. SREBP-dependent lipidomic reprogramming as a broad-spectrum antiviral target. Nat Commun. 2019 Jan 10;10(1):120. doi:10.1038/s41467-018-08015-x. PMID:30631056.

[7] To KK, Lau CC, Woo PC, Lau SK, Chan JF, Chan KH, Zhang AJ, Chen H, Yuen KY. Human H7N9 virus induces a more pronounced pro-inflammatory cytokine but an attenuated interferon response in human bronchial epithelial cells when compared with an epidemiologically-linked chicken H7N9 virus. Virol J. 2016 Mar 15;13:42. doi:10.1186/s12985-016-0498-2. PMID:26975414.

[8] Yan B, Chu H, Yang D, Sze KH, Lai PM, Yuan S, Shuai H, Wang Y, Kao RY, Chan JF, Yuen KY. Characterization of the Lipidomic Profile of Human Coronavirus-Infected Cells: Implications for Lipid Metabolism Remodeling upon Coronavirus Replication. Viruses. 2019 Jan 16;11(1):73. doi:10.3390/v11010073. PMID:30654597.

[9] Burnum-Johnson KE, Kyle JE, Eisfeld AJ, Casey CP, Stratton KG, Gonzalez JF, Habyarimana F et al. MPLEx: a method for simultaneous pathogen inactivation and extraction of samples for multi-omics profiling. Analyst. 2017 Jan 26;142(3):442-448. doi:10.1039/c6an02486f. PMID:28091625.

protocols.name: Extraction
protocols.description:
50 µl of cell suspension was used for DNA extraction for data normalization[1]. The cells were lysed by adding 2 ml of MPLEx solution (-20 °C chloroform/methanol; 2:1, v/v containing IS and butylated hydroxytoluene [BHT]) was added to the tubes, followed by vortexing and centrifugation at 4500 r.p.m. for 10 min at 4 °C. The bottom phase was transferred to glass vials and was evaporated to dryness in a Labconco Centrivap cold trap concentrator.


To ensure that the virus was inactivated after the lysis (after adding MPLEx solution and vortexing), 100 µl of the solution was added to MDCK cells and RD cells for influenza virus and rhinovirus, respectively. Cytopathic effect was examined daily for 3 d[2].


The UPLC-ESI-Q-TOF-MS analysis was performed according to a previously described protocol with slight modifications[3][4]. The dried samples were reconstituted in 25 µl chloroform-methanol (1:1, v/v) and were diluted to 10x the original volume of cell lysate in 225 µl IPA-ACN-water (2:1:1, v/v/v) for LC-MS analysis.


Ref:

[1] Silva LP, Lorenzi PL, Purwaha P, Yong V, Hawke DH, Weinstein JN. Measurement of DNA concentration as a normalization strategy for metabolomic data from adherent cell lines. Anal Chem. 2013 Oct 15;85(20):9536-42. doi:10.1021/ac401559v. PMID:24011029.

[2] Yan B, Chu H, Yang D, Sze KH, Lai PM, Yuan S, Shuai H, Wang Y, Kao RY, Chan JF, Yuen KY. Characterization of the Lipidomic Profile of Human Coronavirus-Infected Cells: Implications for Lipid Metabolism Remodeling upon Coronavirus Replication. Viruses. 2019 Jan 16;11(1):73. doi:10.3390/v11010073. PMID:30654597.

[3] Yuan S, Chu H, Chan JF, Ye ZW, Wen L, Yan B, Lai PM, Tee KM, Huang J et al. SREBP-dependent lipidomic reprogramming as a broad-spectrum antiviral target. Nat Commun. 2019 Jan 10;10(1):120. doi:10.1038/s41467-018-08015-x. PMID:30631056.

[4] Burnum-Johnson KE, Kyle JE, Eisfeld AJ, Casey CP, Stratton KG, Gonzalez JF, Habyarimana F et al. MPLEx: a method for simultaneous pathogen inactivation and extraction of samples for multi-omics profiling. Analyst. 2017 Jan 26;142(3):442-448. doi:10.1039/c6an02486f. PMID:28091625.

protocols.name: Chromatography
protocols.description: The cell lipid extract was analysed using an Acquity UPLC system coupled to a Synapt G2-HDMS mass spectrometer system (Waters Corp., MA, USA). The chromatography was performed on a Waters ACQUITY BEH C18 column (1.7 µm, 2.1 x 100 mm, I.D., 1.7 mm, Waters, Milford, MA, USA). The mobile phase consisted of (A) 0.1% acetic acid in water and (B) acetonitrile. Gradient elution applied for UPLC-MS analysis was described in Table S1 of the paper associated with this study. The column and auto-sampler temperature were maintained at 45 and 10 °C, respectively. The injection volume was 5 µl.

protocols.name: Mass spectrometry
protocols.description:
The mass spectral data were acquired using a Waters Synapt G2-HDMS mass spectrometer in both positive and negative modes. The capillary voltage, sampling cone voltage and source offset were maintained at 2.5 kV, 60 V, and 60 V, respectively. Nitrogen was used as desolvation gas at a ﬂow rate of 800 L/h. The source and desolvation temperatures were maintained at 120 and 400 °C, respectively. Mass spectra were acquired over the m/z range of 50 to 1200. The SYNAPT G2-Si HDMS system was calibrated using sodium format clusters and operated in sensitivity mode. Leucine enkephalin was used as a lock mass for all experiments. The MS data acquired mode is MSE for lipids profile and MS/MS acquisition was operated in the same parameter as in MS acquisition for lipids identification[1].


Ref:

[1] Yang Z, Hou JJ, Qi P, Yang M, Yan BP, Bi QR, Feng RH, Yang WZ, Wu WY, Guo DA. Colon-derived uremic biomarkers induced by the acute toxicity of Kansui radix: A metabolomics study of rat plasma and intestinal contents by UPLC-QTOF-MS(E). J Chromatogr B Analyt Technol Biomed Life Sci. 2016 Jul 15;1026:193-203. doi:10.1016/j.jchromb.2015.09.022. PMID:26433353.

protocols.name: Data transformation
protocols.description:
Acquisition of the raw data was performed using MassLynx software version 4.1 (Waters Corp., MA, USA) and raw data were converted into the Analysis Base File (ABF) format by Reifycs ABF Converter software (https://www.reifycs.com/AbfConverter/)[1]. Converted data were subsequently deconvolved into mass features list including annotation lipid name, accurate mass, retention time and corresponding intensity using the MS-DIAL software (http://prime.psc.riken.jp/Metabolomics_Software/MS-DIAL/)[2]. The total ion intensities of all mass features in the MS-DIAL report list for each sample were normalized by the corresponding DNA concentration to calibrate for cell count variations[3].


Metaboanalyst 4.0 (http://www.metaboanalyst.ca) was used for univariate and multivariate statistical analysis for the normalized mass features list[4]. For univariate analysis, statistical signiﬁcance of features was determined among the mock, IAV infected and RV infected groups using the Student’s t-test, respectively. The false discovery rate (FDR) adjusted P-value <0.05, fold change >1.25 or <0.8 were used as the criteria for selecting signiﬁcant features. For multivariate analysis, the features were subjected to Pareto scaling firstly then partial least squares discriminant analysis (PLS-DA) was performed as a supervised method to find important variables with discriminative power. The PLS-DA model was evaluated with the relevant R2 and Q2. The Variable Importance in Projection (VIP), which reflects both the loading weights for each component and the variability of the response explained by this component, was used for feature selection[5].


Refs:

[1] Kind T, Liu KH, Lee DY, DeFelice B, Meissen JK, Fiehn O. LipidBlast in silico tandem mass spectrometry database for lipid identification. Nat Methods. 2013 Aug;10(8):755-8. doi:10.1038/nmeth.2551. PMID:23817071.

[2] Tsugawa H, Cajka T, Kind T, Ma Y, Higgins B, Ikeda K, Kanazawa M, VanderGheynst J, Fiehn O, Arita M. MS-DIAL:data-independent MS/MS deconvolution for comprehensive metabolome analysis. Nat Methods. 2015 Jun;12(6):523-6. doi:10.1038/nmeth.3393. PMID:25938372.

[3] Silva LP, Lorenzi PL, Purwaha P, Yong V, Hawke DH, Weinstein JN. Measurement of DNA concentration as a normalization strategy for metabolomic data from adherent cell lines. Anal Chem. 2013 Oct 15;85(20):9536-42. doi:10.1021/ac401559v. PMID:24011029.

[4] Chong J, Soufan O, Li C, Caraus I, Li S, Bourque G, Wishart DS, Xia J. MetaboAnalyst 4.0: towards more transparent and integrative metabolomics analysis. Nucleic Acids Res. 2018 Jul 2;46(W1):W486-W494. doi:10.1093/nar/gky310. PMID:29762782.

[5] Galindo-Prieto B, Eriksson L, Trygg J. Variable influence on projection (VIP) for orthogonal projections to latent structures (OPLS). J Chemom 2014;28:623–632. doi:10.1002/cem.2627.

protocols.name: Metabolite identification
protocols.description:
The protocol of lipid identification was carried out according to published procedures[1][2][3]. The statistically signiﬁcant mass features were given annotation names by MS-DIAL once the MS features could match internal library criterion. Furthermore, these annotated significant mass features were selected for validation using MS/MS experiments.


All putative lipids were identified using exact molecular weights, nitrogen rule, MS2 fragment and literature/database searches including METLIN database (http://metlin.scripps.edu/), MassBank of North America (MoNA, http://mona.fiehnlab.ucdavis.edu/) and LipidMaps (http://www.lipidmaps.org/). For final confirmation of lipids identity using authentic chemical standard, MS/MS fragmentation pattern of the chemical standard was compared with that of candidate lipids under the same LC-MS condition.



Refs:

[1] Tsugawa H, Cajka T, Kind T, Ma Y, Higgins B, Ikeda K, Kanazawa M, VanderGheynst J, Fiehn O, Arita M. MS-DIAL:data-independent MS/MS deconvolution for comprehensive metabolome analysis. Nat Methods. 2015 Jun;12(6):523-6. doi:10.1038/nmeth.3393. PMID:25938372.

[2] Zhu ZJ, Schultz AW, Wang J, Johnson CH, Yannone SM, Patti GJ, Siuzdak G. Liquid chromatography quadrupole time-of-flight mass spectrometry characterization of metabolites guided by the METLIN database. Nat Protoc. 2013 Mar;8(3):451-60. doi:10.1038/nprot.2013.004. PMID:23391889.

[3] Yan B, Deng Y, Hou J, Bi Q, Yang M, Jiang B, Liu X, Wu W, Guo D. UHPLC-LTQ-Orbitrap MS combined with spike-in method for plasma metabonomics analysis of acute myocardial ischemia rats and pretreatment effect of Danqi Tongmai tablet. Mol Biosyst. 2015 Feb;11(2):486-96. doi:10.1039/c4mb00529e. PMID:25418780.
